channel.title: Digg Top Stories
channel.description: Digg - What the Internet is talking about right now

item.title: The Boston Cowboy
item.description: He had gone to the marathon to honor his dead sons. By the end of the day, Carlos Arredondo was a hero.

item.title: Boston Marathon Bombing Updates
item.description: Two bombs exploded in the crowded streets near the finish line of the Boston Marathon on Monday, killing three people and injuring more than 130 in a bloody scene of shattered glass and severed limbs that raised alarms that terrorists might have struck again in the U.S.

item.title: The Hunt For The Boston Marathon Bomber
item.description: The hunt for the killer behind Monday’s Boston Marathon bombings began within minutes of the attacks.

item.title: These Photographs Swept The Pulitzer Prizes
item.description: Rodrigo Abd, Manu Brabo, Narciso Contreras, Khalil Hamra and Muhammed Muheisen of The Associated Press have won the 2013 Pulitzer Prize in breaking news photography for their coverage of Syria’s civil war.

item.title: YouTube Stars: Where Are They Now?
item.description: A compilation of the greatest youtube video sensations and viral videos and where they are now.

item.title: How To Tweet (And How Not To Tweet) During A National Tragedy
item.description: A journalist's guide to tweeting during a crisis.

item.title: From Earth To Mars
item.description: One planet lived and the other died. Can the Curiosity rover discover why?

item.title: How Police Use Social Media To Track Terror
item.description: Yesterday's attack at the Boston Marathon offered law enforcement officials a glimpse at the good, the bad, and the social that comes with a criminal investigation in the iPhone, Twitter, and YouTube era.

item.title: How Apple Lost Its Cool
item.description: If you have to tell someone you’re cool, or your product is cool, you aren’t, and it isn’t. Right now, Apple has to tell people it and its products are cool.

item.title: Cracking The Voynich Code
item.description: The quixotic quest to read meaning in the patterns of a bizarre manuscript that has bedeviled scholars for years.

item.title: What Is A 'False Flag' Attack – And Was Boston One?
item.description: During the Boston Police Department's final press conference of a confounding and deadly day, someone in the audience asked if Monday's bombing was a "false flag" attack.

item.title: Hundreds Feared Dead After 7.8 Earthquake Strikes Iran
item.description: A major earthquake struck Iran near the border with Pakistan on Tuesday and an Iranian official said hundreds of people were feared to have been killed.

item.title: Studying Subway Riders' Quirks
item.description: Stand, or sit in a crowded row, brushing thighs with strangers?

item.title: What Are Astronauts Taking Photos Of?
item.description: Astronauts take a lot of photos of Earth, for personal use and for specific experiments on board the International Space Station. NASA saves them on a server, and now a data cruncher has mapped them all.

item.title: Is It Legal To Shut Down Cellular Networks In An Emergency?
item.description: Yes, but the FCC has been trying to clarify how and when it should happen.

item.title: CRAPCHA, Impossible CAPTCHA Tests That Pranks Web Users
item.description: The Completely Ridiculous And Phony Captcha that Hassles for Amusement (CRAPCHA) is an embeddable fake CAPTCHA test that is intentionally indecipherable and impossible to complete.

item.title: 11 Of The Most Unusual Elevators
item.description: Elevators have a simple task: take passengers from one floor to another safely. But it doesn't mean that they have to be boring.

item.title: Documenting The High-Flying World Of Parkour
item.description: Andy Day has a hard time separating photography from parkour.

item.title: IRS Gives Boston-Area Taxpayers More Time
item.description: The Internal Revenue Serve says Boston-area taxpayers need time to finish their tax returns without worry.

item.title: Old Faithful's Hidden Cavern Discovered
item.description: Old Faithful's underground plumbing looks more like a bagpipe than a flute, a new study of the Yellowstone National Park geyser finds.

item.title: Celebrating The Nearing End Of The Humble Computer Cursor
item.description: After 50 years of pointing and clicking, we are celebrating the nearing end of the computer cursor with a music video where all our cursors can be seen together for one last time.

item.title: Can Olive Oil Save Sagging Mediterranean Economies?
item.description: A new report says emerging countries like China and Brazil are hungry for the stuff.

item.title: The Boston Marathon Bombing From A Runner's POV
item.description: A runner caught the first explosion on camera.

item.title: Former NFL Player Saved A Victim From Boston Marathon Explosions
item.description: Joe Andruzzi spent nine seasons in the NFL as an offensive lineman who protected the quarterback from defensive players. Six years removed from playing in the league, Andruzzi still has that mentality ingrained in his being.

item.title: The Enemy Industrial Complex
item.description: How to turn a world lacking in enemies into the most threatening place in the universe.

item.title: Google Reveals Glass Specs
item.description: One-day battery life, bone conduction audio, and 16GB storage.

item.title: 5 Americans Who Defected To North Korea
item.description: It's not only people from authoritarian regimes that occasionally defect. Sometimes people defect to authoritarian regimes.

item.title: What's A 'Crude' Bomb, Anyway?
item.description: The answer is two-fold: electronics and chemicals.

item.title: There's A New Theory For What Causes Migraine
item.description: New study suggests that we have been misunderstanding the cause of migraine headaches for decades.

item.title: Google Plans Retail Stores
item.description: The stores will promote all of Google's flagship products — including Glass.

item.title: 10 Hedge Fund Managers Each Make More Money Than The 10 Best-Paid CEOs Combined
item.description: Ever wonder where the real money is? In hedge funds, of course!
